analyzed: vuttam ha etam bhagavatā vuttam arahatā iti me suta
translated: This was said by the Blessed One, said by the Arahant, so I have heard:

analyzed: sikkhānisasā bhikkhave viharatha paññuttarāḥ vimutti sārā sata ādhipateyyā
translated: “Monks, dwell with the training’s benefits as your focus, with discernment foremost, with release as your heart’s core, with mindfulness as your presiding factor.

original: Sikkhānisaṁsānaṁ, bhikkhave, viharataṁ paññuttarānaṁ vimuttisārānaṁ satādhipateyyānaṁ dvinnaṁ phalānaṁ aññataraṁ phalaṁ pāṭikaṅkhaṁ—
analyzed: bhikkhave viharatam paññuttarānam vimutti sārānam sata ādhipateyyānam dvinnam phalānam aññataram phalam pāṭikaṅkha
translated: For those who dwell with the training’s benefits as their focus, with discernment foremost, with release as their heart’s core, with mindfulness as their presiding factor, one of two fruits can be expected:

original: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā, sati vā upādisese anāgāmitā”ti.🔽Etamatthaṁ bhagavā avoca.
analyzed: diṭṭhā iva dhamme aññā sati vā upādisese anāgāmi tā ti  etam attham bhagavān avoca
translated: either gnosis right here & now, or—if there be any remnant of clinging-sustenance—non-return.”🔽This is the meaning of what the Blessed One said.
“The one whose training is complete, who is subject to no falling away,🔽with discernment foremost, who sees the ending of birth,

analyzed: pañca uttaram  tam ve munim antima deha dhāri
translated: the sage who bears his last body,
I call a conqueror of Death, gone beyond old age.
So always delighting in jhāna, unified,
ardent, seeing the ending of birth,
conquer Māra with his mount, monks,

original: Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
analyzed: ayam pi atthaḥ vuttaḥ bhagavatā iti me sutam ti
translated: This is the meaning of what the Blessed One said in “Thus have I heard.”
The ninth section on “Thus have I heard” is finished.
